||bgcolor=| ||''[[2018–19 Serbian Cup|QF]]''||[[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] – [[2018–19 UEFA Champions League#Group Stage|Group Stage]]||align=left|{{flagicon|}} || ||{{ref|q|17}} |} :1{{note|a}} Goals in all competitions are counted. :2{{note|b}} First title in domestic cup competitions. :3{{note|c}} First title in domestic league competitions. :4{{note|d}} The 1952 season was shortened and sped-up. The reason for the changes was a desire to implement the fall-spring competition format. Competition took place in two phases. In first clubs were divided into two preliminary groups of 6 teams each. Based on their ranking at the end of preliminary groups they were promoted to three groups: Title, Central and Relegation. Each of them containing 4 teams. :5{{note|e}} Cup competition was not held for 1955–56 and 1974–75 seasons. :6{{note|f}} First season in which club entered European competitions. :7{{note|g}} First final in European competitions. :8{{note|h}} Between 1988-89 and 1991-92, drawn games went to penalties with the winners of the shoot out gaining the point. Figures in brackets represent points won in such shoot outs. :9{{note|i}} First European title. :10{{note|j}} First season of [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]]'s League. :11{{note|k}} Was unable to compete in European competitions due to UN sanctions. :12{{note|l}} Between 1993-94 and 1995-96 league was divided into 2 groups, A and B, of 10 teams each. In the first half of competition teams played each other twice, and based on number of points won and their position, each team was given certain amonunt of "bonus points". In the start of spring part of competition 4 last teams from A league were drop to B league, and replaced by top 4 teams from B league. Again teams played each others twice, and in the end final positions were determined by sum of points won at the end of Spring part of competition and bonus points won in the Fall part of competition. :13{{note|m}} From this season onward for victory was awarded 3 points instead of 2. :14{{note|n}} First season of [[Serbia and Montenegro]]'s League. :15{{note|o}} First season of [[Serbian SuperLiga]]. :16{{note|p}} Managed to qualify for group stage and advance through it for the first time since [[UEFA Europa League]] was established in 2009. :17{{note|q}} Managed to qualify for group stage for the first time since [[UEFA Champions League]] was established in 1992. {{Red Star Belgrade}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Red Star Belgrade Seasons}} [[Category:Red Star Belgrade seasons| ]] [[Category:Serbian football club seasons]] [[Category:Belgrade-related lists]]

page.title: List of birds of Christmas Island

revision.text:
The '''Birds of''' '''[[Christmas Island]]''' form a heterogeneous group of over 100 species. There is a core group of ten [[endemism|endemics]] that have evolved on the remote island in the eastern [[Indian Ocean]] for thousands of years, attended by a suite of regular migrants, opportunists and occasional visitors. Some 200 km from the nearest land, [[Java]], Christmas Island was not occupied by humans until the late 19th century. It is now an [[Australia]]n territory. The natural vegetation of most of the 140 km² island is [[rainforest]], to which the endemic landbirds are adapted, while the [[seabird]]s have taken advantage of a breeding location which had no major natural predators.
After over a century of human exploitation of the [[phosphate]] deposits covering much of the island, two thirds of the rainforest cover remains and is now protected as a [[national park]]. However, gaps where the forest has been cleared, and the introduction of exotic fauna, continue to destabilise the island’s [[biological diversity]]. The endemic [[Abbott's booby]] is threatened when nesting by wind turbulence caused by past forest clearance. However, the biggest immediate threat is the introduction and spread of [[yellow crazy ant]]s, through both direct predation and ecosystem collapse. This has led to all the island’s endemic bird species and subspecies being classified as [[Critically Endangered]].
Meanwhile, the number of species recorded from Christmas Island continues to increase as [[birder]]s, especially from Australia, attracted by the island’s endemics, record a variety of vagrants previously unnoticed. Some of these may in time, as with the [[white-breasted waterhen]], establish breeding populations. Christmas Island is now seen as a birding ‘hot spot’, not only for its endemics but also for the chance of recording new species for the Australian bird list, something reflected in the frequency of submissions of sightings to the [[Royal Australasian Ornithologists Union|Birds Australia]] Rarities Committee.
==List of birds==
===[[Phasianidae]]=== * [[Red junglefowl]], ''[[Gallus gallus]]'' - introduced, hybridising with feral domestic fowl
===[[Anatidae]]=== * [[Garganey]], ''[[Spatula querquedula]]'' - vagrant
===[[Procellariidae]]=== * [[Bulwer's petrel]], ''[[Bulweria bulwerii]]'' - vagrant * [[Barau's petrel]], ''[[Pterodroma baraui]]'' - vagrant * [[Wedge-tailed shearwater]], ''[[Ardenna pacificus]]'' - vagrant
===[[Hydrobatidae]]=== * [[Matsudaira's storm petrel]], ''[[Oceanodroma matsudairae]]'' - vagrant
===[[Phaethontidae]]=== * [[White-tailed tropicbird]], ''[[Phaethon lepturus|Phaethon lepturus fulvus]]'' - endemic subspecies * [[Red-tailed tropicbird]], ''[[Phaethon rubricauda]]'' - breeding
===[[Sulidae]]=== * [[Abbott's booby]], ''[[Papasula abbotti]]'' - endemic species * [[Brown booby]], ''[[Sula leucogaster]]'' - breeding * [[Red-footed booby]], ''[[Sula sula]]'' - breeding
===[[Phalacrocoracidae]]=== * [[Great cormorant]], ''[[Phalacrocorax carbo]]'' - vagrant * [[Little black cormorant]], ''[[Phalacrocorax sulcirostris]]'' - vagrant
===[[Fregatidae]]=== * [[Christmas frigatebird]], ''[[Fregata andrewsi]]'' - endemic species * [[Lesser frigatebird]], ''[[Fregata ariel]]'' - regular visitor * [[Great frigatebird]], ''[[Fregata minor]]'' - breeding
===[[Pelecanidae]]=== * [[Australian pelican]], ''[[Pelecanus conspicillatus]]'' - vagrant
===[[Ardeidae]]=== * [[Great egret]], ''[[Ardea alba]]'' - vagrant * [[Cattle egret]], ''[[Ardea ibis]]'' - vagrant * [[Intermediate egret]], ''[[Ardea intermedia]]'' - vagrant * [[White-faced heron]], ''[[Ardea novaehollandiae]]'' - breeding * [[Chinese pond heron]], ''[[Ardeola bacchus]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/> * [[Javan pond heron]], ''[[Ardeola speciosa]]'' - vagrant * [[Striated heron]], ''[[Butorides striatus]]'' - vagrant * [[Little egret]], ''[[Egretta garzetta]]'' - vagrant * [[Eastern reef egret]], ''[[Egretta sacra]]'' - breeding * [[Malayan night heron]], ''[[Gorsachius melanolophus]]'' - vagrant * [[Japanese night heron]], ''[[Gorsachius goisagi]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/> * [[Cinnamon bittern]], ''[[Ixobrychus cinnamomeus]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/> * [[Schrenck's bittern]], ''[[Ixobrychus eurhythmus]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/> * [[Black bittern]], ''[[Ixobrychus flavicollis]]'' - vagrant * [[Yellow bittern]], ''[[Ixobrychus sinensis]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/> * [[Nankeen night heron]], ''[[Nycticorax caledonicus]]'' - vagrant
===[[Threskiornithidae]]=== * [[Glossy ibis]], ''[[Plegadis falcinellus]]'' - vagrant
===[[Accipitridae]]=== * [[Christmas Island goshawk]], ''[[Accipiter natalis]]'' - endemic species * [[Chinese goshawk]], ''[[Accipiter soloensis]]'' - vagrant<ref name=bma>Birding-Aus mailing list archives</ref> * [[Japanese sparrowhawk]], ''[[Accipiter gularis]]'' - vagrant<ref name=bma/> * [[White-bellied sea eagle]], ''[[Haliaeetus leucogaster]]'' - vagrant * [[Crested honey buzzard]], ''[[Pernis ptilorhynchus]]'' - vagrant
===[[Falconidae]]=== * [[Nankeen kestrel]], ''[[Falco cenchroides]]'' - breeding * [[Peregrine falcon]], ''[[Falco peregrinus]]'' - vagrant * [[Northern hobby]], ''[[Falco subbuteo]]'' - vagrant
===[[Rallidae]]=== * [[White-breasted waterhen]], ''[[Amaurornis phoenicurus]]'' - breeding * [[Eurasian coot]], ''[[Fulica atra]]'' - vagrant * [[Watercock]], ''[[Gallicrex cinerea]]'' - vagrant * [[Ruddy-breasted crake]], ''[[Porzana fusca]]'' - vagrant * [[Black-tailed nativehen]], ''[[Tribonyx ventralis]]'' - vagrant
===[[Scolopacidae]]=== * [[Common sandpiper]], ''[[Actitis hypoleucos]]'' - regular visitor * [[Ruddy turnstone]], ''[[Arenaria interpres]]'' - regular visitor * [[Sharp-tailed sandpiper]], ''[[Calidris acuminata]]'' - vagrant * [[Sanderling]], ''[[Calidris alba]]'' - regular visitor * [[Curlew sandpiper]], ''[[Calidris ferruginea]]'' - vagrant * [[Red-necked stint]], ''[[Calidris ruficollis]]'' - regular visitor * [[Long-toed stint]], ''[[Calidris subminuta]]'' - vagrant * [[Great knot]], ''[[Calidris tenuirostris]]'' - vagrant * [[Pin-tailed snipe]], ''[[Gallinago stenura]]'' - vagrant * [[Bar-tailed godwit]], ''[[Limosa lapponica]]'' - vagrant * [[Little curlew]], ''[[Numenius minutus]]'' - vagrant * [[Whimbrel]], ''[[Numenius phaeopus]]'' - regular visitor * [[Grey-tailed tattler]], ''[[Tringa brevipes]]'' - vagrant * [[Wood sandpiper]], ''[[Tringa glareola]]'' - regular visitor * [[Common greenshank]], ''[[Tringa nebularia]]'' - regular visitor * [[Marsh sandpiper]], ''[[Tringa stagnatilis]]'' - vagrant * [[Terek sandpiper]], ''[[Xenus cinereus]]'' - vagrant * [[Common redshank]], ''[[Tringa totanus]]'' - vagrant
===[[Haematopodidae]]=== * [[Sooty oystercatcher]], ''[[Haematopus fuliginosus]]'' - vagrant
===[[Recurvirostridae]]=== * [[Black-winged stilt]], ''[[Himantopus himantopus]]'' - vagrant
===[[Charadriidae]]=== * [[Little ringed plover]], ''[[Charadrius dubius]]'' - vagrant * [[Greater sand plover]], ''[[Charadrius leschenaultii]]'' - regular visitor * [[Lesser sand plover]], ''[[Charadrius mongolus]]'' - regular visitor * [[Oriental plover]], ''[[Charadrius veredus]]'' - vagrant * [[Pacific golden plover]], ''[[Pluvialis fulva]]'' - regular visitor * [[Grey plover]], ''[[Pluvialis squatarola]]'' - vagrant * [[Masked lapwing]], ''[[Vanellus miles]]'' - vagrant
===[[Glareolidae]]=== * [[Oriental pratincole]], ''[[Glareola maldivarum]]'' - vagrant * [[Australian pratincole]], ''[[Stiltia isabella]]'' - vagrant
===[[Laridae]]=== * [[Common noddy]], ''[[Anous stolidus]]'' - breeding * [[Lesser noddy]], ''[[Anous tenuirostris]]'' - vagrant * [[Whiskered tern]], ''[[Chlidonias hybrida]]'' - vagrant * [[White tern]], ''[[Gygis alba]]'' - vagrant * [[Common gull]], ''[[Larus canus]]'' - vagrant * [[Arctic jaeger]], ''[[Stercorarius parasiticus]]'' - vagrant * [[Greater crested tern]], ''[[Thalasseus bergii]]'' - vagrant * [[Sooty tern]], ''[[Onychoprion fuscatus]]'' - vagrant
===[[Columbidae]]=== * [[Christmas emerald dove]], ''[[Chalcophaps indica natalis]]'' - endemic subspecies * [[Pied imperial pigeon]], ''[[Ducula bicolor]]'' - vagrant * [[Christmas imperial pigeon]], ''[[Ducula whartoni]]'' - endemic species * [[Red turtle dove]], ''[[Streptopelia tranquebarica]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/>
===[[Psittaculidae]]=== * [[Rose-ringed parakeet]], ''[[Psittacula krameri]]'' - introduced, breeding?
===[[Cuculidae]]=== * [[Horsfield's bronze cuckoo]], ''[[Chrysococcyx basalis]]'' - vagrant * [[Pallid cuckoo]], ''[[Cuculus pallidus]]'' - vagrant * [[Oriental cuckoo]], ''[[Cuculus saturatus]]'' - vagrant * [[Asian koel]], ''[[Eudynamys scolopacea]]'' - vagrant * [[Large hawk-cuckoo]], ''[[Hierococcyx sparverioides]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/>
===[[Strigidae]]=== * [[Christmas Island hawk-owl]], ''[[Ninox natalis]]'' - endemic species
===[[Caprimulgidae]]=== * [[Savanna nightjar]], ''[[Caprimulgus affinis]]'' - vagrant
===[[Apodidae]]=== * [[Pacific swift]], ''[[Apus pacificus]]'' - vagrant * [[House swift]], ''[[Apus affinis]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/> * [[Needletail]], ''[[Hirundapus]]'' sp. - vagrant * [[Christmas Island swiftlet]], ''[[Collocalia natalis]]'' - endemic species
===[[Alcedinidae]]=== * [[Common kingfisher]], ''[[Alcedo atthis]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/>
===[[Halcyonidae]]=== * [[Collared kingfisher]], ''[[Todiramphus chloris]]'' - vagrant * [[Sacred kingfisher]], ''[[Todiramphus sanctus]]'' - vagrant
===[[Coraciidae]]=== * [[Dollarbird]], ''[[Eurystomus orientalis]]'' - vagrant
===[[Pittidae]]=== * [[Blue-winged pitta]], ''[[Pitta moluccensis]]'' - vagrant
===[[Laniidae]]=== * [[Brown shrike]], ''[[Lanius cristatus]]'' - vagrant * [[Tiger shrike]], ''[[Lanius tigrinus]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc>Birds Australia Rarities Committee</ref>
===[[Motacillidae]]=== * [[White wagtail]], ''[[Motacilla alba]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/> * [[Grey wagtail]], ''[[Motacilla cinerea]]'' - regular visitor * [[Western yellow wagtail|Yellow wagtail]], ''[[Motacilla flava]]'' - vagrant * [[Citrine wagtail]], ''[[Motacilla citreola]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/>
===[[Passeridae]]=== * [[Java sparrow]], ''[[Padda oryzivora]]'' - introduced, breeding * [[Eurasian tree sparrow]], ''[[Passer montanus]]'' - breeding
===[[Swallow|Hirundinidae]]=== * [[Asian house martin]], ''[[Delichon dasypus]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/> * [[Red-rumped swallow]], ''[[Hirundo daurica]]'' - vagrant * [[Tree martin]], ''[[Hirundo nigricans]]'' - vagrant * [[Barn swallow]], ''[[Hirundo rustica]]'' - regular visitor
===[[Acrocephalidae]]=== * [[Oriental reed warbler]], ''[[Acrocephalus orientalis]]'' - vagrant<ref name=bma/>
===[[Megaluridae]]=== * [[Pallas's grasshopper warbler]], ''[[Locustella certhiola]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/>
===[[White-eye|Zosteropidae]]=== * [[Christmas Island white-eye]], ''[[Zosterops natalis]]'' - endemic species
===[[Muscicapidae]]=== * [[Blue-and-white flycatcher]], ''[[Cyanoptila cyanomelana]]'' - vagrant<ref name=barc/> * [[Christmas thrush]], ''[[Turdus poliocephalus erythropleurus]]'' - endemic subspecies
===[[Sturnidae]]=== * [[Daurian starling]], ''[[Agropsar sturninus]]'' - vagrant
==References==

This is a list of notable people from [[Port Elizabeth]], in South Africa.
== Notable people == *[[Saki Macozoma]] - former political prisoner, businessman <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://venturesafrica.com/africas-secret-millionaires-sakumzi-saki-macozoma/|title=Africa's Secret Millionaires: Sakumzi "Saki" Macozoma - Ventures Africa|date=2012-12-06|work=Ventures Africa|access-date=2018-05-19|language=en-US}}</ref> *[[Ashton Nyte]] - musician<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ashtonnyte.com|title=Ashton Nyte|website=Ashton Nyte|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Karl Bauermeister]] - cricketer<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/player/44172.html|title=Karl Bauermeister|website=Espncricinfo|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Johan Botha (cricketer)|Johan Botha]] – cricketer<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/southafrica/content/player/44149.html|title=Johan Botha|website=Espncricinfo|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Schalk Burger]] – rugby union player; 2004 [[IRB International Player of the Year]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.espn.co.uk/southafrica/rugby/player/14355.html|title=Schalk Burger|website=Espn UK|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Adrienne Camp]] – singer-songwriter<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ifnigeria.net/adrienne-adie-camp-biography/|title=Adrienne ‘Adie’ Camp Biography|website=ifNigeria|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Thinus Delport]] – rugby union player<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.espn.co.uk/southafrica/rugby/player/13428.html|title=Thinus Delport|website=Espn UK|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Gabriella Demetriades]] – model<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tollywood3.in/2016/05/gabriella-demetriades-biography-wiki-height-weight-and-more.html|title=Gabriella Demetriades Biography,Wiki Height Weight And More|website=Tollywood3.IN|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Russell Domingo]] – cricket coach<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/southafrica/content/player/634397.html|title=Russell Domingo|website=ESPNcricinfo|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Athol Fugard]] – Playwright, novelist<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iainfisher.com/fugard/athol-fugard.html|title=Athol Fugard biography|website=Iain Fisher|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Danie Gerber]] – rugby union player<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rugbyworld.com/rugby-positions/centres/danie-gerber-65393|title=The greatest centres of all time: Danie Gerber|website=Rugby World|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Danny Williams (singer)|Danny Williams]] - best known for his rendition of [[Moon River|Moon River theme song]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2005/dec/15/guardianobituaries.film1|title=Obituary: Danny Williams|last=Laing|first=Dave|date=2005-12-15|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-04}}</ref> *[[Danny Jordaan]] – 2010 FIFA world cup organising committee boss<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://safexec.co.za/home/biography-of-danny-jordaan/|title=Danny Jordaan|website=SAFEXEC|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Len Killeen]] – rugby union player<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/players/len-killeen/summary.html|title=Len Killian: Career Stats & Summary|website=Rugby League Project|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Daine Klate]] - football (soccer) player{{cn|date=March 2018}} *[[Siya Kolisi]] – rugby union Player<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tvsa.co.za/actors/viewactor.aspx?actorid=8557|title=Zolani Mahola|website=TVSA|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Zolani Mahola]] – actress and singer-songwriter with the band [[Freshlyground]] *[[Shashi Naidoo]] – actress and TV anchor<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3244816/bio|title=Shashi Naidoo|website=IMDB|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Zim Ngqawana]] – jazz musician<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/people/zimasile-ngqawana|title=Zimasile Ngqawana|website=SA History|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Winston Ntshona]] – playwright and actor<ref>[https://www.heraldlive.co.za/news/2018-08-02-theatre-doyen-winston-ntshona-dies/ Theatre doyen Winston Ntshona dies]</ref> *[[Wayne Parnell]] – cricketer<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/southafrica/content/player/265564.html|title=Wayne Parnell|website=ESPNcricinfo|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Alviro Petersen]] – cricketer<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/southafrica/content/player/46934.html|title=Alviro Petersen|website=ESPNcricinfo|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Robin Peterson]] – cricketer<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/southafrica/content/player/46750.html|title=Robin Peterson|website=ESPNcricinfo|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Shawn Phillips]] – singer-songwriter<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/shawn-phillips-mn0000016617/biography|title=Shaun Phillips|website=All Music|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Graeme Pollock]] – cricketer<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/southafrica/content/player/46772.html|title=Greame Pollock|website=ESPNcricinfo|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Peter Pollock]] – cricketer<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/southafrica/content/player/46770.html|title=Peter Pollock|website=ESPNcricinfo|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Shaun Pollock]] – cricketer<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/southafrica/content/player/46774.html|title=Shaun Pollock|website=ESPNcricinfo|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Ashwell Prince]] – cricketer<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/southafrica/content/player/46788.html|title=AShwell Prince|website=ESPNcricinfo|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Patrick Soon-Shiong]] – billionaire entrepreneur and philanthropist; part-owner of the LA Lakers; graduate of PE's Chinese High School<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/patrick-soon-shiong/|title=Patrick Soon-Shiong|website=Forbes|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Reeva Steenkamp]] – model<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.africansuccess.org/visuFiche.php?id=1069&lang=en|title=Biography of Reeva STEENKAMP|website=African Succes|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Mzwandile Stick]] – rugby union player; former captain of the [[South Africa national rugby sevens team|National 7s Team]]; Backline coach for the South African Rugby Team.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.espn.co.uk/southafrica/rugby/player/247999.html|title=Mzwandile Stick|website=ESPN UK|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Joe van Niekerk]] – rugby union player<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.espn.co.uk/southafrica/rugby/player/13724.html|title=Joe van Niekerk|website=ESPN UK|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Charlton Tobias]] Charlie T, comedian and radio personality<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.algoafm.co.za/Blogs/210/Daron-Mann-Breakfast|title=Daron Mann Breakfast|website=Algoa FM|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> *[[Nikki Williams]] – singer-songwriter *[[Mzi Mahola]] - poet and author living in [[Zwide, Eastern Cape Province, South Africa|Zwide]] township<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.poetryinternationalweb.net/pi/site/poet/item/5383/10/Mzi-Mahola|title=Mzi Mahola|website=Poetry International Web|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref>
==References== <references/>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} ==List of Rulers of Welayta== The following were the rulers of the Wolayta kingdom and province in present-day southern [[Ethiopia]]. {| class="wikitable" |- align=left ! width="18%"|Tenure ! width="40%"|Incumbent ! width="20%"|Notes |- valign=top |''c.''1250||colspan="2"|''Foundation of [[Wolayta people|Welayta]](As unwritten sources shows, state of Wolayta existed during Axum empire and even before. There more than 42 dynasties. Wolayta Mala and Tigrean Dynasty are the last and recent ones.) state'' |- valign=top |colspan="2"|'''[[Kingdom of Damot|Damot dynasty]]'''|| |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |||''Kawo Motole(Motolomi)''|| |- valign=top |colspan="2"|'''Wolaita Mala dynasty'''|| |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |||''Dates and rulers not known''||Ended with the [[Great Oromo migration|Oromo migrations]] |- valign=top |colspan="3"|'''[[Tigre dynasty (Walayta)|Tigre dynasty]]''' |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |''c.''1560||'''[[Mikael of Walayta|Mikael]]''', Kawa||  |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |16th century||'''[[Girma (Tigray dynasty)|Girma]]''', Kawa|| |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |17th century||'''[[Gazenja]]''', Kawa
(Gazenya)|| |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |17th century||'''[[Addayo]]''', Kawa|| |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |18th century||'''[[Kote of Walayta|Kote]]''', Kawa|| |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |18th century||'''[[Libana]]''', Kawa|| |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |???? to 1761||'''[[Tube of Walayta|Tube]]''', Kawo||Died in office |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |1761 to 1800||'''[[Ogatto]]''', Kawo|| |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |1800 to 1835||'''[[Amado of Walayta|Amado]]''', Kawo|| |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |1835 to 1845||'''[[Damota]]''', Kawo|| |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |1845 to 1886||'''[[Gobe of Walayta|Gobe]]''', Kawo|| |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |1886 to c.1890||'''[[Gaga of Walayta|Gaga]]''', Kawo|| |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |1890 to ''October 1895''||'''[[Tona of Walayta|Tona]]''', Kawo|| |- valign=top |colspan="3"|''Waylata conquered by [[Menelik II of Ethiopia]] and incorporated into [[Ethiopia]] 1894 |- valign=top bgcolor="#ffffec" |''October 1895'' to 1900||'''[[Tekle Haymanot of Gojjam|Tekle Haymanot]]''', ''[[Ethiopian aristocratic and religious titles|Negus]]''|| |} ==Sources== * C.F. Beckingham and G.W.B. Huntingford, ''Some Records of Ethiopia, 1593–1646'' (London: [[Hakluyt Society]], 1954), pp. lxv – lxvii. ==See also== *[[Monarchies of Ethiopia]] *[[Rulers and heads of state of Ethiopia]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Welayta, List Of Rulers Of}} [[Category:Ethiopia-related lists|Walayta]] [[Category:Lists of African monarchs|Walayta]] [[Category:Rulers of Ethiopia| ]]

{{multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=October 2012}} {{refimprove|date=October 2012}} }} This is a '''list of [[sculpture park]]s''', by country. {{Expand list|date=May 2014}} {{TOC right|limit=3}}
==Africa==
===South Africa=== *Sculpture Garden of the [[Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden]], [[Cape Town]]<ref name="C4WDefault-8726922">{{cite web|url=http://www.sanbi.org/gardens/kirstenbosch/virtualtour/kirstenbosch-nbg-sculpture-garden |title=Kirstenbosch NBG: Sculpture Garden |work=sanbi.org |date=May 28, 2013 |accessdate=April 14, 2014 |author= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415002816/http://www.sanbi.org/gardens/kirstenbosch/virtualtour/kirstenbosch-nbg-sculpture-garden |archivedate=April 15, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} *Nirox Sculpture Garden, 1 hour drive away from Johannesburg {{cite web|url=http://niroxarts.com |title=Nirox: Sculpture Garden |date=June 24, 2015 }}</ref> *[http://niroxarts.com/ Nirox Foundation Sculpture Park], Johannesburg.
===Zimbabwe=== *[[Chapungu Sculpture Park]], Harare
==Asia==

Birkbeck, University of London |publisher=bbk.ac.uk |date=2010-02-01 |accessdate=2010-10-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://community.travelchinaguide.com/review2.asp?i=821 |title=The World’s Largest Urban Sculpture Park: A Guide |publisher=community.travelchinaguide.com |date=2006-09-25 |accessdate=2010-10-02}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ccfao.com.cn/ CCFAO.com.cn] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20080629143945/http://www.ccfao.com.cn/ Web Archive])</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://zjrc.changchun.jl.cn/cc?ID=120704000000000000 It is one of the finest examples of a sculpture park in Europe, with in their collection art of [[Auguste Rodin]], [[Henry Moore]], [[Barbara Hepworth]], [[Richard Serra]], [[Jean Dubuffet]], [[Mark di Suvero]], [[Lucio Fontana]], [[Fritz Wotruba]] and [[Claes Oldenburg]].

===United Kingdom=== *[http://williambeningtongallery.co.uk/sculptural/ Contemporary Sculpture Fulmer], [[Fulmer]], England [[File:Barbara Hepworth Sculpture Garden, St Ives - geograph.org.uk - 11244.jpg|thumb|150px|''[[Sphere with Inner Form]]'' at the [[Barbara Hepworth Museum]] in Trewyn Garden, [[St Ives, Cornwall]], with ''[[Two Forms (Divided Circle)]]'' behind]] *[[Artparks Sculpture Park]], in [[Guernsey]] and elsewhere in the UK *[[Barbara Hepworth Museum]], in [[St Ives, Cornwall|St Ives]], [[Cornwall]], south-west [[England]], preserves [[Barbara Hepworth]]'s studio and garden much as they were when she lived and worked there<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.artlyst.com/articles/barbara-hepworth-drawings-displayed-in-major-wakefield-exhibition| title=Barbara Hepworth Drawings Displayed in Major Wakefield Exhibition - ArtLyst| publisher=Artlyst| accessdate=30 October 2012| quote=The studio was designated the Barbara Hepworth Museum in the following year and, on coming under the Tate's aegis in 1980, secured an unrivalled collection of her work for the Gallery.}}</ref> *[[Broomhill Sculpture Gardens]], in [[Muddiford, Barnstaple]], [[North Devon]], south-west [[England]]. A collection of over 300 sculptures sited in 15 acres of woodland garden and river meadow. *[[Cass Sculpture Foundation]], [[West Sussex]], England<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.goodwood.co.uk/revival/news-and-coverage/articles/the-cass-sculpture-foundation.aspx| title=The Cass Sculpture Foundation| accessdate=30 October 2012| quote=Since 1992, the Cass Sculpture Foundation has commissioned over 400 new monumental sculptures from emerging and established British sculptors. There are currently over 80 works on display in the 26-acre grounds of the charity at Goodwood, West Sussex.| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120730081520/http://www.goodwood.co.uk/revival/news-and-coverage/articles/the-cass-sculpture-foundation.aspx| archivedate=30 July 2012| df=}}</ref> *[[Chatsworth House]] in Derbyshire. While not a sculpture park as such, the owners of Chatsworth, the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, have collected and commissioned sculpture to be permanently sited on the estate. These include works by [[Barry Flanagan]], [[Elisabeth Frink]], and [[William Turnbull (artist)|William Turnbull]] in the garden, and commissions by artists Tim Harrisson, [[David Nash (artist)|David Nash]], [[Allen Jones (sculptor)|Allen Jones]], Nigel Ross and Alison Crowther in the {{convert|1000|acre|adj=on}} park designed by [[Capability Brown]]. Since 2006 Chatsworth has hosted 'Beyond Limits', a modern and contemporary sculpture exhibition in the gardens, in conjunction with Sotheby's auction house. This landmark selling exhibition takes place during the months of September and October, annually. *[[Churt]], [[Surrey]] is home to The Sculpture Park, an exhibition located in an arboretum and water garden.<ref>https://www.thesculpturepark.com/</ref> *[[Forest of Dean Sculpture Trail]] in the [[Forest of Dean]] in the [[county]] of [[Gloucestershire]], England; links several different site-specific sculptures commissioned for the forest *Wyndcliffe Court Sculpture Garden, two exhibitions throughout the year, Spring and Summer with an ever-changing exhibit. *[[Grizedale Forest]] sculpture trail *[[Irwell Sculpture Trail]], the largest [[public art]] scheme in the [[United Kingdom]], commissioning regional, national and international artists. It follows a well established {{convert|30|mi|km|sing=on}} footpath stretching from [[Salford Quays]] through [[Bury, Greater Manchester|Bury]] into [[Rossendale]] and up to the [[Pennines]] above [[Bacup]].<ref>The Irwell Sculpture Trail is not strictly a park, since it is defined by a trail.</ref> *[[Jupiter Artland]], near Edinburgh *[[Tout Quarry|Tout Quarry Sculpture Park]], [[Isle of Portland]], [[Dorset]], the first sculpture park in a quarry in the UK. Started in 1983 by the [[Portland Sculpture and Quarry Trust]]. Includes the work "Still Falling" by [[Antony Gormley]]. Tout Quarry is an international venue for a yearly programme of [[stone carving]] and sculpture courses that teach skills in [[direct carving]], [[lettercutting]], [[relief carving]] and architectural detail. Tout Quarry is also a creative and educational resource for visitors, schools, colleges and universities who come to learn about stone through the Portland Sculpture and Quarry Trust. *[[Yorkshire Sculpture Park]], [[West Yorkshire]], England *[[Elemental Sculpture Park]], [[Cirencester]]. ===Australia=== [[File:MCSP04.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Torus - Hidden and revealed, Adrian Page, 2003, [[McClelland Gallery and Sculpture Park]], Langwarrin, Victoria]] * [[Heide Museum of Modern Art]] Sculpture Park in [[Bulleen, Victoria|Bulleen]] near [[Melbourne]]. Sculptures are permanently exhibited. * Lyons Sculpture Park,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lyonssculpturepark.com.au |title=Lyonssculpturepark.com.au |publisher=Lyonssculpturepark.com.au |date=2017-11-24 |accessdate=2017-11-24}}</ref> {{convert|15|acre|m2|adj=on}} sculpture park in Lyons, western [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] * [[McClelland Gallery and Sculpture Park]], public sculpture garden in [[Langwarrin, Victoria|Langwarrin]] near [[Melbourne]] * [[National Gallery of Australia#Sculpture garden|National Gallery of Australia]] has a sculpture park from the gallery to the banks of [[Lake Burley Griffin]].<ref name = "garden">{{cite web |title= Art in Landscape, by Harijs Piekains |publisher= National Gallery of Australia |url= http://nga.gov.au/sculpturegarden/essay.htm |accessdate= 2007-07-29}}</ref> One of the permanent exhibits in the park is a fern garden designed by [[Fiona Margaret Hall|Fiona Hall]].<ref name="hall">{{cite web|title=Fiona Hall's fern garden, by Harijs Piekains |publisher=National Gallery of Australia |url=http://nga.gov.au/sculpturegarden/fernGarden.htm |accessdate=2007-07-29 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070707054252/http://www.nga.gov.au/sculpturegarden/fernGarden.htm |archivedate=2007-07-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===New Zealand=== * [[Gibbs Farm]], Kaipara, Northland * [[Hills Golf Course]] Sculpture Trail, [[Arrowtown]], Otago * [[Hotere Garden Oputae]], Port Chalmers, Otago * [[Waitakaruru Arboretum]], Waitakaruru, Waikato
==South America==
===Brazil=== [[File:Inhotim yayoi kusama 05.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Sculpture by [[Yayoi Kusama]], [[Inhotim]], [[Brumadinho]], Brazil]] *[[Inhotim|Centro de Arte Contemporânea Inhotim]], [[Brumadinho]], Minas Gerais
===Colombia=== [[File:Cabeza-Plaza Botero.jpg|thumb|right|150px|''Head'', [[Botero Plaza]], [[Medellín]], Colombia]] *[[Botero Plaza]], [[Medellín]] *[[Hacienda Nápoles]], the estate created by [[drug lord]] [[Pablo Escobar]] and now owned by the Colombian government,<ref name="Arbuckle, Alex Q">{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2016/01/24/pablo-escobar-hacienda/|date=August 29, 1989|title=Hacienda Nápoles: What do you buy the drug lord who has everything? A zoo|author=Arbuckle, Alex Q. }}</ref> boasts of some statues of [[dinosaur]]s<ref name="Arbuckle, Alex Q"/> (built with bones),{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} and pre-historic animals (such as the [[Woolly mammoth|mammoth]], that children can climb and play on),{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} as well as decommissioned military vehicles, and a giant hand sculpture.<ref name="Arbuckle, Alex Q"/> *[[Nutibara sculpture park]], [[Medellín]]

''A Guide to the Sculpture Parks and Gardens of America''. revision.comment: /* Road mapping and highway facility management */
revision.text:
[[File:Google_Street_View_Car_in_Honolulu.jpg|180px|thumb|right|[[Google Street View]] Car]]
'''Mobile mapping''' is the process of collecting [[geospatial]] data from a mobile [[vehicle]],<ref>Vitrià, et al. (2004) [https://books.google.com/books?id=P7FYs0IvbpoC&lpg=PA209&dq=mobile%20mapping&pg=PA69#v=onepage&q=mobile%20mapping&f=false p.69] Retrieved June 2011.</ref> typically fitted with a range of [[photographic]], [[radar]], [[laser scanning|laser]], [[LiDAR]] or any number of [[remote sensing]] systems. Such systems are composed of an integrated array of time synchronised [[navigation]] sensors and [[Photography|imaging]] sensors mounted on a mobile platform.<ref>Hofmann-Wellenhof, B., et al. (2003) [https://books.google.com/books?id=losWr9UDRasC&lpg=PA379&dq=mobile%20mapping&pg=PA379#v=onepage&q=mobile%20mapping&f=false p.379-380.] Retrieved June 2011.</ref> The primary output from such systems include [[GIS]] data, digital [[map]]s, and [[georeference]]d images and video.
== History ==
The development of direct reading [[georeference|georeferencing]] technologies opened the way for mobile mapping systems. [[GPS]] and [[Inertial Navigation System]]s, have allowed rapid and accurate determination of [[Location (geography)|position]] and [[:wikt:attitude|attitude]] of [[remote sensing]] equipment,<ref>Tao, C. V. (2007) [https://books.google.com/books?id=tWUfPdng_o0C&lpg=PP1&dq=mobile%20mapping&pg=PA5#v=onepage&q&f=false p.5.] Retrieved June 2011</ref> effectively leading to direct mapping of features of interest without the need for complex post-processing of observed data.
== Applications ==
=== Aerial mobile mapping ===
Traditional [[Topographic surveying and mapping|techniques]] of geo-referencing aerial photography, [[ground profiling radar]], or [[Lidar]] are prohibitively expensive, particularly in inaccessible areas, or where the type of data collected makes interpretation of individual features difficult. Image direct georeferencing, simplifies the mapping control for large scale mapping tasks.<ref>Gao, J. (2009) [https://books.google.com/books?id=KHXSKc1bfusC&lpg=PA196&dq=mobile%20mapping&pg=PA196#v=onepage&q=mobile%20mapping&f=false p.196.] Retrieved June 2011.</ref>
=== Emergency response planning ===
Mobile mapping systems allow rapid collection of data to allow accurate assessment of conditions on the ground.<ref>[[Sisi Zlatanova|Zlatanova]], et al. (2008) [https://books.google.com/books?id=m-2RMTpe7WEC&lpg=PA103&dq=mobile%20mapping&pg=PA103#v=onepage&q=mobile%20mapping&f=false p.103.] Retrieved June 2011.</ref>
=== Internet applications ===
Internet, and [[mobile device]] users, are increasingly utilising geo-spatial information, either in the form of mapping, or geo-referenced imaging. Google, Microsoft, and Yahoo have adapted both aerial photographs and satellite images to develop online mapping systems. ''[[Google Street View|Street View]]'' type images are also an increasing market.<ref>Tao, C.V. (2007) [https://books.google.com/books?id=tWUfPdng_o0C&lpg=PP1&dq=mobile%20mapping&pg=PR13#v=onepage&q&f=false p.xiii.] Retrieved June 2011.</ref>
Location aware [[PDA]] systems rely on geo-referenced features collated from mobile mapping sources.<ref>Weng, Q. (2009) [https://books.google.com/books?id=VtXSBy4-UH0C&lpg=PA70&dq=mobile%20mapping&pg=PA70#v=onepage&q=mobile%20mapping&f=false p.70.] Retrieved June 2011.</ref>
=== Road mapping and highway facility management ===
GPS combined with digital camera systems allow rapid update of road maps.<ref>Tao, C.V. (2009) [https://books.google.com/books?id=KHXSKc1bfusC&lpg=PA614&dq=mobile%20mapping&pg=PA614#v=onepage&q=mobile%20mapping&f=false p.614.] Retrieved June 2011.</ref> <ref>Hammoudi et al. (2013) [https://doi.org/10.5772%2F56570 p.10.] Retrieved November 2018.</ref> <ref>Hammoudi et al. (2013) [https://dx.doi.org/10.4028/www.scientific.net/AMM.332.139 p.139-144.] Retrieved January 2016.</ref> The same system can be utilised to carry out efficient road condition surveys,<ref>Zlatanova, et al. (2008) [https://books.google.com/books?id=m-2RMTpe7WEC&lpg=PA103&dq=mobile%20mapping&pg=PA113#v=onepage&q=mobile%20mapping&f=false p.113.] Retrieved June 2011.</ref> and facilities management.<ref>Gavrilova, M.L. (2006) [https://books.google.com/books?id=WsTq5xvLKiEC&lpg=PA997&dq=mobile%20mapping&pg=PA996#v=onepage&q=mobile%20mapping&f=false p.996-1001.] Retrieved June 2011.</ref> [[Laser scanning]] technologies, applied in the mobile mapping sense, allow full 3D data collection of slope, bankings, etc.<ref>van Oosterom, P. (2008) [https://books.google.com/books?id=j5Vt4W69YfAC&lpg=PA7&dq=mobile%20mapping&pg=PA8#v=onepage&q=mobile%20mapping&f=false p.8.] Retrieved June 2011</ref>
== Footnotes ==
{{reflist}}
== References ==
* Tao, C. V. (2007) ''Advances in mobile mapping technology: Volume 4 of International Society for Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing book series''. Taylor & Francis. {{ISBN|0-415-42723-1}} * Gao, J. (2009) ''Digital Analysis of Remotely Sensed Imagery''. McGraw Hill Professional. {{ISBN|0-07-160465-0}}. * Zlatanova, S. & Li, J. (2008) ''Geospatial Information Technology for Emergency Response: Volume 6 of International Society for Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing book series''. Routledge. {{ISBN|0-415-42247-7}}. * van Oosterom, Peter (2008) ''Advances in 3D geoinformation systems: Lecture notes in geoinformation and cartography''. Springer. {{ISBN|3-540-72134-7}}. * Hofmann-Wellenhof, B., Legat, K., Wieser, M. (2003) ''Navigation: principles of positioning and guidance'' Springer. {{ISBN|3-211-00828-4}}. * Vitrià, J., Radeva, P., Aguiló, I. (2004) ''Recent advances in artificial intelligence research and development: Volume 113 of Frontiers in artificial intelligence and applications''. IOS Press. {{ISBN|1-58603-466-9}}. * Gavrilova, M.L. (2006) ''Computational science and its applications: ICCSA 2006 : international conference, Glasgow, UK, May 8–11, 2006 : proceedings''. Springer. {{ISBN|3-540-34072-6}}. * Weng, Q. (2009) ''Remote Sensing and GIS Integration: Theories, Methods, and Applications'' McGraw Hill Professional. {{ISBN|0-07-160653-X}}.

revision.text:
{{Infobox lake | name = Oguta Lake | native_name = Ogbuide, Ughamiri | native_name_lang = ig | image = Oguta Lake.JPG | caption = | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = [[Imo State]] | coords = {{coord|5|42|24|N|6|47|33|E|region:NG_type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | type = | inflow = Utu, [[Awbana River|Awbana]], [[Orashi River|Orashi]] and [[Njaba River|Njaba]] rivers | outflow = | catchment = | basin_countries = Nigeria | length = | width = | area = | depth = | max-depth = {{convert|8|m|abbr=on}} | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | islands = | cities = |embedded = {{Designation list | embed = yes | designation1 = Ramsar | designation1_date = 30 April 2008 | designation1_number = 1757<ref>{{Cite web|title=Oguta Lake|website=[[Ramsar Convention|Ramsar]] Sites Information Service|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/1757|accessdate=25 April 2018}}</ref>}} }} '''Oguta Lake''' is a lean 'finger lake' formed by the damming of the lower [[Njaba River]] with alluvium.<ref name="ReferenceJ">{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=XyyxCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA355&lpg=PA355&dq=okwelle&source=bl&ots=jcmrldePu1&sig=AM_vCLasJ40dL1QEF3AXSvPAqXg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjYg8ew3e7MAhVlGsAKHXepC0U4MhDoAQg7MAY#v=onepage&q=okwelle&f=false |title=Eastern Nigeria|first= Barry|last=Floyd|date=1969 |page=89 |publisher=Springer|accessdate=May 22, 2016}}</ref> It is the largest natural lake in [[Imo State]], Southeastern [[Nigeria]];<ref name="http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu">{{cite journal|url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.402.4399&rep=rep1&type=pdf |title=Inventory of the Quaternary Geology and the Evolution of the Oguta Lake, in Southeastern Nigeria|first= Bruno Ndicho|last=NFOR et al |journal= World Journal of Engineering and Pure and Applied Science |issue=2249-0582 |date=2012 |page=2 |volume=2:1|publisher=Department of Geology, Anambra State University, Uli, Anambra State, Nigeria|display-authors=etal}}</ref> within the equatorial [[rainforest]] region of [[Niger Delta]].<ref name="www.iiste.org">{{cite journal|url=http://www.iiste.org/Journals/index.php/JNSR/article/download/.../13026 |title=Assessment of Water Quality and Heavy Metal levels of Fish Species in Oguta Lake, Imo State Nigeria|first= JOHNBOSCO EMEKA|last=UMUNNAKWE |journal=Journal of Natural Sciences Research |issue=2225-0921 |date=2014 |page=1 |volume=4|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Oguta Lake's catchment area comprises the drainage area of the [[Njaba River]] and a part of the [[River Niger]] floodplain in the region south of [[Onitsha]].<ref name="rsis.ramsar.org">{{cite journal|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/RISapp/files/RISrep/NG1757RIS.pdf |title=Oguta Lake|first=Prof. O.O.|last=OGUNKOYA |journal=Information Sheet on Ramsar Wetlands(RIS) |issue=2006-2008 |date=2007 |page=4}}</ref>
==Location== The lake is situated in [[Oguta]] about thirty miles (48.27 km) from the junction of the [[Ogba–Egbema–Ndoni|Ndoni]] and [[Orashi River]].It is a fine piece of water, being about five miles (8.05 km) long from east to west and a mile and half (2.41 km) wide.<ref name="onlineresearchjournals.com">{{cite journal|url=http://onlineresearchjournals.com/aajoss/art/77.pdf |title=The Aro, Host Communities And Continuties In Intergroup Suspicion In The Oguta Area Since Pre-colonial Times |page=1 |first=Uche Uwaezuoke |last=Okonkwo |journal=Afro Asian Journal of Social Sciences |volume=2 |issue=2.4 |date=2011 |issn=2229-5313}}</ref> The stream from [[Njaba River]] is the major inflow to Oguta Lake.<ref name="onlineresearchjournals.com">{{cite journal|url=http://onlineresearchjournals.com/aajoss/art/77.pdf |title=The Aro, Host Communities And Continuties In Intergroup Suspicion In The Oguta Area Since Pre-colonial Times |page=1 |first=Uche Uwaezuoke |last=Okonkwo |journal=Afro Asian Journal of Social Sciences |volume=2 |issue=2.4 |date=2011 |issn=2229-5313}}</ref> The other 3 tributaries are [[Awbana River|Awbana]], Utu and [[Orashi River|Orashi]]. The [[Orashi River]] flows past Oguta Lake in its southwestern portion.
==Economic Importance== The lake is important to the people of oil-rich [[Njaba River]] basin including [[Oguta]], [[Orsu]], [[Mgbidi]], [[Nkwesi]], [[Osemotor]], [[Awo-Omamma]] and [[Izombe]] as a source of water, fish, tourism and an outlet for [[sanitary sewer|sewerage]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ilec.or.jp/database/afr/afr-18.html |title=OGUTA LAKE |publisher=www.ilec.or.jp |accessdate=2008-06-08}}</ref> Uhamiri is the goddess of the Lake.<ref>{{cite book|title=Igbo women and economic transformation in southeastern Nigeria, 1900-1960 |first=Gloria |last=Chuku |publisher=Routledge |year=2005 |isbn=0-415-97210-8 |page=26}}</ref>
==Trade Route== The river route [[Njaba River|Njaba]] and [[Orashi River|Orashi]] via Oguta Lake to the coast, passing through [[Awo-omamma]], [[Mgbidi]], [[Oguta]], [[Ogba–Egbema–Ndoni|Ndoni]], [[Abonnema]], made [[Oguta]], [[Osemotor]], [[Awo-omamma]] and surrounding towns important commercial centres of international trade mainly for oil palm.<ref name="onlineresearchjournals.com">{{cite journal|url=http://onlineresearchjournals.com/aajoss/art/77.pdf |title=The Aro, Host Communities And Continuties In Intergroup Suspicion In The Oguta Area Since Pre-colonial Times |page=1 |first=Uche Uwaezuoke |last=Okonkwo |journal=Afro Asian Journal of Social Sciences |volume=2 |issue=2.4 |date=2011 |issn=2229-5313}}</ref> Oguta Lake also served as a [[Biafra]]n army marine base during the [[Nigerian Civil War]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldlakes.org/lakedetails.asp?lakeid=8355|title=LakeNet -Lakes|publisher=www.worldlakes.org|accessdate=2008-06-08}}</ref>
==Footnotes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ilec.or.jp/database/afr/afr-18.html World lakes database]
