Italy: 31 December 2016 ==Society== [[File:Language distribution in South Tyrol and Trentino.png|thumb|left|Language distribution in [[Trentino-Alto Adige|Trentino-South Tyrol]].]] ===Language distribution=== Tyrol can be subdivided into 5 different language groups. In addition to the majority languages such as German and Italian, languages such as [[Ladin language|Ladin]], [[Cimbrian language|Cimbrian]] and [[Mócheno language|Mócheno]] are also spoken. The last three languages are recognized as minority languages. These language groups are mostly located in the Trentino-Alto Adige region and are thus promoted and protected by the region. The Ladin language is also spoken outside the region in [[Souramont]] ([[Province of Belluno]]). Ladin is considered a [[Rhaeto-Romance language]]. The [[Cimbrian language]] is also used in various linguistic islands ([[Sette Comuni]]) outside the region of Trentino-South Tyrol. The Cimbrian language is considered an upper-Bavarian dialect. ====Dialects==== In state of [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrol]], the German language is used by a large majority. As in many other regions in German-speaking countries, Tyrol also has its own German-language dialect. The Tyrolean dialect comes from the [[Bavarian language|Bavarian]] dialect. In [[South Tyrol]], the Tyrolean dialect was mixed with a few individual Italian words. Due to the difficult accessibility of the valleys in earlier years, many other valleys developed a slightly differentiated dialect compared to the Tyrolean. The Italian language group in South Tyrol mostly uses the Italian standard language and does not speak any dialect. The Ladin language also has no uniform language, so every valley also has a slight difference in [[Ladinia]]. The majority in [[Trentino]] speaks its own Italian dialect. This dialect has slightly Venetian features, mixed with words from the German-Bavarian dialect. ==Heraldry== : ''See {{ill|Coat of arms of Tyrol|de|Tiroler Wappen}}'' Although the details of the arms of Tyrol have changed over the centuries, one feature has remained more-or-less constant: ''[[argent]]'', an [[Eagle (heraldry)#Eagle displayed|eagle displayed]] ''[[gules]]'', armed (and sometimes crowned) ''[[Or (heraldry)|or]]''.{{cite book| |title=A Complete Guide to Heraldry |first=A. C. |last=Fox-Davies |authorlink=Arthur Charles Fox-Davies |year=1909 |pages=234-235 |publisher=[[Thomas Nelson (publisher)|Thomas Nelson and Sons Ltd]]}} Since 1983, the Province of [[South Tyrol]] has its own coat of arms. It is very similar to the coat of arms of the State of [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrol]]. The Province wanted to emphasize the historical commonality of the countries. {{cite web|url=http://www.provinz.bz.it/politik-recht-aussenbeziehungen/autonomie/wappen-banner-symbole-autonomie.asp|title= Wappen und Banner: Symbole der Autonomie|publisher= Province of South Tyrol|access-date=2018-01-11}} The Province of [[Trentino|Trento]] received its coat of arms in 1340 and refers to the [[bishopric of Trent|prince-bishopric of Trento]]. The former [[County of Tyrol]] had a uniform coat of arms, which was slightly changed over the centuries. File:Tirol Wappen.PNG|Coat of arms of [[Tyrol (State)]] File:Suedtirol CoA.svg|Coat of arms of the [[provinces of Italy|Province]] of [[South Tyrol]] File:Trentino CoA.svg|Coat of arms of the Province of [[Trentino]] File:Coat of arms of Trentino-South Tyrol.svg|Coat of arms of the [[regions of Italy|Region]] of [[Trentino-Alto Adige|Trentino–South Tyrol]] File:Wappen Gefürstete Grafschaft Tirol.png|Coat of arms of the former [[County of Tyrol]] during the [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]] ==History== {{seealso|History of Tyrol}} [[File:Emil Rau - A Summer’s Day in Tyrol.jpg|thumb|Traditional costumes of Tyrol]] ===Prehistory=== {{no references|section|date=July 2017}} The earliest archaeological records of human settlement in Tyrol have been found in the [[Tischofer Cave]]. They date from the [[Palaeolithic]], about 28,000-27,000 [[years BP|BP]]. The same cave has also yielded evidence of human occupation during the [[Bronze Age]] (very roughly, 4000-3000 BP (2000–1000 BC)). In 1991, the mummified remains of a man who had died around 3300-3100 BC were discovered in a glacier in the [[Ötztal Alps]], in Tyrol. Researchers have called him [[Ötzi]] (and also other names, including "The Iceman"). He lived during the [[Chalcolithic]] or Copper Age, after man had learned how to exploit copper but before man had learned how to make bronze. His body and belongings were very well-preserved, and have been subjected to detailed scientific study. They are preserved in the [[South Tyrol Museum of Archaeology]], [[Bolzano]], South Tyrol, Italy. There is evidence that Tyrol was a centre for copper mining in the 4th millennium BC; for example, at [[Brixlegg]]. There is also evidence of the [[Urnfield culture]] (roughly 1300–750 BC). Evidence of the [[La Tène culture]] (roughly 450–100 BC, during the [[Iron Age]]) has also been found; as has evidence of the [[Fritzens-Sanzeno culture]] from about the same period. Towards the end of that time, Tyrol began to be noted in Roman written records. The inhabitants may have been [[Illyrians]], in the process of being displaced by [[Celts]] (perhaps themselves displaced from [[Noricum]] by [[Slavs]]). There are also indications that [[Adriatic Veneti]] may have been present in the south of the region. The Romans called them [[Rhaetians]]; although it is not clear whether that then meant a specific tribe or confederation of tribes, or was a broader term for the inhabitants of the area. They made wine barrels (an idea which the Romans took from them), and had their own alphabet. ===Roman times=== {{no references|section|date=July 2017}} In 15 BC, Tyrol was conquered by Roman forces commanded by [[Nero Claudius Drusus Germanicus|Drusus]] and [[Tiberius]]. The Romans established [[Raetia]] and [[Noricum]] as [[Roman province|province]]s of the [[Roman Empire]]. Raetia included Vinschgau, Burggrafenamt, Eisacktal, Wipptal, Oberinntal and parts of the Unterinntal. Noricum included Pustertal, Defereggen and parts of the Unterinntal to the right of the Ziller and the Inn. [[Bolzano]] and the extreme south of Tyrol belonged to the province of [[Triveneto|Venetia et Histria]]. The inhabitants adopted [[vulgar Latin]], and combined it with their own languages. The result was [[Romansh language|Romansh]], which is still spoken today and is one of the official languages of Switzerland. The Romans constructed [[Roman roads|metalled roads]] guarded by [[Roman fort|fort]]s through Tyrol to connect the Italian peninsula and the lands beyond; notably the [[Via Claudia Augusta]] and the {{ill|Via Raetia|de}}. The Romans did not seem to find Tyrol an attractive area in which to build new towns, because there are few of them. One town they did build was [[Aguntum]], near modern [[Lienz]]. In late antiquity (from AD 476), Tyrol belonged to the [[Ostrogoths]], and it was included in the [[Ostrogothic Kingdom]]. In 534, the Ostrogoths lost Merrano, Val Venosta and Passer to the [[Franks]]. The Ostrogothic Kingdom collapsed in 553, after being overrun by {{ill|Bajuvarians|de|Bajuwaren}} from the north and [[Lombards]] from the south. The Lombards established the [[Duchy of Tridentum]] (or, Trent; roughly corresponding to modern [[Trentino]]) in south Tyrol. [[Slavic people]]s, who had recently taken [[Carinthia]] from the Bajuvarians, settled in east Tyrol. ===Middle Ages=== {{no references|section|date=July 2017}} {{main|County of Tyrol}} Most of Tyrol came under the control of the [[Duchy of Bavaria]] (created {{circa|555}}). The southern parts, including Bolzano, [[Salorno]], and the right bank of the [[Adige]] (including [[Eppan an der Weinstraße|Eppan]] and [[Kaltern an der Weinstraße|Kaltern]]) remained under the Lombards. Tyrol was christianised through the bishoprics of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Bolzano-Brixen|Brixen]] and [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Trento|Triento]]. The frontier remained the same though [[Carolingian Empire|Carolingian]] and [[Ottonian dynasty|Ottonian]] times. The area was subject to ''Stammensgerechte'' ([[Ancient Germanic law]]s), such as ''Lex Romana Curiensis'' (see [[Raetia Curiensis]]), ''[[Lex Alamannorum]]'', ''[[Lex Baiuvariorum]]'' and ''[[Leges Langobardorum]]''. [[File:Am Schloss Tirol.jpg|thumb|left|[[Tyrol Castle]] in [[Tirol, South Tyrol|Tirol]], near [[Merano]].]] In 1027, Emperor [[Conrad II, Holy Roman Emperor|Conrad II]], in order to secure the important route through the [[Brenner Pass]], allotted the left bank of the Adige (from [[Lana, South Tyrol|Lana]] to [[Mezzocorona]]) to the Duchy of Bavaria. During the 12th century, the local nobility went further: they built [[Tyrol Castle]] in the modern ''[[comune]]'' of [[Tirol, South Tyrol|Tirol]] in South Tyrol, near modern [[Merano]]; and around 1140, established the [[County of Tyrol]] as a state within the Holy Roman Empire. The Counts of Tyrol were at first ''[[Vogt]]'' (underlords) subject to the Bishoprics of Brixen and Triento; but they had other ideas. They expanded their holdings at those bishoprics' expense. They displaced competing nobles like the {{ill|House of Eppan|de|Eppan (Adelsgeschlecht)}}, and declared their independence from the Duchy of Bavaria; though not without dispute. In 1228, they conceded the {{ill|Saalforste|de}} to the [[House of Wittelsbach]], rulers of Bavaria; as a result, that area remains part of Bavaria to this day. In 1253, rulership of the County passed by inheritance to the [[Meinhardiner|Meinhardiner family]]. In 1335, the last male heir to the Meinhardiner lands, [[Henry of Bohemia]], died. His daughter, [[Margaret, Countess of Tyrol|Margaret]], thereupon became Countess of Tyrol; but her title was in doubt because of different laws in different lands as to what a woman could or could not inherit. She navigated her way between the competing claims of the Houses of Wittelsbach, [[House of Luxembourg|Luxembourg]] and [[Habsburg]] by, in 1342, marrying [[Louis V, Duke of Bavaria|Louis of Wittelsbach]]. Louis died in 1361. Margaret died in 1369, and bequeathed Tyrol to [[Rudolf IV, Duke of Austria|Rudolf of Habsburg]]. The various dynastic squabbles were resolved that same year by the {{ill|Treaty of Schärding|de|Frieden von Schärding}}, under which (for suitable compensation) the Wittelsbachs agreed to relinquish their claims to Tyrol in favour of the Habsburgs. When the Habsburgs took control of Tyrol, it had roughly its modern size. However, the [[Unterinntal]] downstream from [[Schwaz]] still belonged to Bavaria; the [[Zillertal]] and [[Brixental]] to [[Salzburg]]; [[Brixen]] and the [[Pustertal]] were episcopal territories, or part of the [[County of Gorizia]]. Therefore, the [[Montafon]] and the [[Unterengadin]] were Tyrolean. Tyrol was of great strategic importance to the Habsburgs. It controlled several important Alpine passes. It connected their landholdings in [[Further Austria]]. In 1406, as the Habsburg lands were split up by inheritance, Tyrol once again became a separate entity (a ''[[Landstand]]''), in which the greater landowners had the right to be consulted (''Mitspracherecht''). During a confusing succession of events, in 1420 [[Frederick IV, Duke of Austria]] moved the capital of Tyrol from [[Meran]] to [[Innsbruck]], and Meran lost its earlier importance. ==Politics== ===Euroregion Tyrol-South Tyrol-Trentino=== {{main|Euroregion Tyrol-South Tyrol-Trentino}} [[File:Dreier Landtag.jpg|thumb|right|Dreier-Landtag]] The [[Euroregion Tyrol-South Tyrol-Trentino]] was founded in 1998. The aim is to strengthen cooperation between the separated countries. {{cite web|url=http://www.europaregion.info/de/willkommen.asp|title=Willkommen|publisher=Euroregion Tyrol-South Tyrol-Trentino|accessdate=2018-01-20}} In several areas, such as mobility, agriculture, education and culture will be tried to promote exchange and to raise the awareness of the cultural and historical heritage of the region of Tyrol in the minds of the population. Cross-border projects will be initiated to improve the relationship between the different language groups. To represent common ideas and values in Europe, the Euroregion has a joint office in [[Brussels]] since 1995. {{cite web|url= http://www.europaregion.info/de/europa.asp|title=Europäische Integration und Euregio|publisher=Euroregion Tyrol-South Tyrol-Trentino|accessdate=2018-01-20}} The headquarters of the office is in [[Bolzano]]. Joint decisions are taken by organized three diet (in German: ''Dreier-Landtag''), which have been held since 1991 mostly every two to three years with the [[Landtag|state Diets]] of Trento (provincial council of Trentino), [[Landtag of South Tyrol|Bolzano]] (provincial council of South Tyrol) and Innsbruck (state council of Tyrol (State)). In 2011, the region was institutionalized and since then has its own legal entity. ===Political Parties=== Political parties in the Italian part of Tyrol (provinces of Bolzano and Trento) include: * [[Partito Democratico]] (PD) * [[Südtiroler Volkspartei]] (SVP) * [[Movimento 5 Stelle|Movimento Cinque Stelle]] (M5S) * [[Lega Nord]] (LN) * [[Greens (South Tyrol)|Greens]] * [[South Tyrolean Freedom]] * [[Die Freiheitlichen]] * [[Trentino Tyrolean Autonomist Party]] (PATT) The Austrian part of Tyrol shares the Austrian party system: * [[Tiroler Volkspartei]]; organization of the [[ÖVP]] in the state of [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrol]], which has dominated local politics since 1945 * [[Social Democratic Party of Austria]] (SPÖ) * [[Freedom Party of Austria]] (FPÖ) * [[The Greens – The Green Alternative]] * [[NEOS - The New Austria and Liberal Forum|NEOS]] The multiplicity of parties is due to the fact that Tyrol lies in two different nation states and thus are politically independent of each other. Another reason for the large number of parties is the great independence of the two Provinces of [[South Tyrol|Bolzano]] and [[Trentino|Trento]]. By the second statute of autonomy in 1972, the province of Bolzano acquired much of the region's competences and since then has been mostly independent of the province of Trento. The second autonomy statute enabled the linguistic minorities to be better protected. {{cite web|url=http://www.provinz.bz.it/politik-recht-aussenbeziehungen/autonomie/autonomiestatut.asp|title=Das Autonomiestatut|publisher=Province of South Tyrol|accessdate=2018-01-20}} The [[regional council of Trentino-South Tyrol]], which consists of the two provincial councils of Bolzano and Trento, has less influence and competences. Thus, many parties determine their focus within the provinces. Other parties in [[Trentino-South Tyrol]], especially in South Tyrol, were founded on the example of Austrian parties and have many similarities with the [[List of political parties in Austria|parties in Austria]]. ==Economy== In the economic sector statistics are shown, which are based largely on numbers and data of the [[Euroregion Tyrol-South Tyrol-Trentino]]. It lacks individual communities that are outside the Euroregion. As there are no 10,000 inhabitants living in these communities, the statistics hardly distort the territory of Tyrol and the remaining 1.8 million inhabitants. Tyrol had a total GDP of 67.6 billion euros in 2014. Divided into individual countries, the State of [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrol]] generated 28.8 billion euros, the Province of [[South Tyrol]] 20.6 billion euros and the Province of [[Trentino]] 18.2 billion euros. {{cite web|url=http://www.europaregion.info/de/zahlen-europaregion.asp|title=ZAHLEN ZUR EUROPAREGION|publisher=Europaregion Tirol-Südtirol-Trentino|accessdate=2018-02-03}} In GDP per capita (2015), that means 39,300 euros/capita in the State of Tyrol, 42,400 euros/capita in South Tyrol and 35,500 euros/capita in Trentino. The unemployment rate in the State of Tyrol is 3.2% (2014), in South Tyrol 3.4% (2017) {{cite web|url=https://www.suedtirolnews.it/wirtschaft/arbeitslosenquote-in-suedtirol-bei-34-prozent|title=Arbeitlosenquote in Südtirol bei 3,4%|publisher=suedtirolnews.it|accessdate=2018-02-03}} and in Trentino 4.6% (2017) {{cite web|url=http://www.ansa.it/trentino/notizie/2017/12/07/istat-in-trentino-disoccupazione-in-calo-46_a8bac161-5a47-431a-95ac-9c678cdd00aa.html|title=Istat, Trentino disoccupazione in calo (4,6%)|publisher=ansa.it|accessdate=2018-02-03}}. The Tyrol region is one of the wealthiest regions in Europe and, in terms of GDP/capita, is above the EU average, which amounted to 28,900 euros/capita in 2015. The Region of [[Trentino-South Tyrol]] is, in terms of GDP/capita, the wealthiest region in Italy with 37,813 euros/capita in 2015. {{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/2995521/7962764/1-30032017-AP-EN.pdf/4e9c09e5-c743-41a5-afc8-eb4aa89913f6|title=2015 GDP per capita in 276 EU regions Four regions over double the EU average… …and still nineteen regions below half of the average|publisher=European Union|accessdate=2018-02-03}} ===Primary sector=== [[File:St-magdalena st-justina-rosengarten.jpg|thumb|right|Vineyards in [[Bolzano]]]] Agriculture and forestry occupy a special position in Tyrol. The many small and medium-sized farms have shaped the landscape and culture in Tyrol for many centuries. In order to be competitive with larger farms outside Tyrol, there is a strong [[cooperative]] system in Tyrol. South of Tyrol, in the Region of [[Trentino-South Tyrol]], the cultivation of apples and wine plays an important role. So every tenth apple in Europe comes from [[South Tyrol]]. {{cite web|url=https://www.idm-suedtirol.com/de/ueber-suedtirol/1-jeder-10-europaeische-apfel-kommt-aus-suedtirol.html|title=Jeder 10. Apfel europäische Apfel kommt aus Südtirol|publisher=IDM Südtirol|accessdate=2018-02-03}} Known wines in Trentino-South Tyrol are the [[Vernatsch]], the [[Lagrein]], the [[Gewürztraminer]] and the [[Weißburgunder]]. {{cite web|url=https://www.suedtirolwein.com/de/suedtirol-wein.html|title=Südtirol Wein|publisher=Südtirol Wein|accessdate=2018-02-03}} Livestock, grazing and forestry are important at higher elevations and in more northerly areas. Mainly cattle, sheep, goats and pigs are kept. {{cite web|url=https://www.tirol.gv.at/fileadmin/themen/statistik-budget/statistik/downloads/Folder_T_ST_T_2015.pdf|title=Zahlen zur Europaregion|publisher=Europaregion Tirol-Südtirol-Trentino|accessdate=2018-02-03}} Accordingly, the production of milk and [[Tyrolean Speck]] in the farms is very important. Horses also play an increasingly important role in livestock, for equestrian sports and farm holidays. The [[Haflinger]] horses are known in the Tyrolean region and originate from [[Hafling]], near [[Merano]]. {{cite web|url=http://www.tt.com/lebensart/freizeit/13610447-91/pferde-in-tirol-das-glück-der-erde-steht-auf-vier-beinen.csp|title=Pferde in Tirol:Das Glück der Erde steht auf vier Beinen|publisher=Tiroler Tageszeitung|accessdate=2018-02-03}} ===Secondary sector=== The first industrialization reached Tyrol late in the 19th century. Most of these were small businesses that were important only in the local area. A second wave of industrialization took place at the beginning of the 20th century. Particularly affected at that time was the city of [[Bolzano]] with the [[Italianization]] policy under the fascism in the 20s. {{cite web|url=http://www.hk-cciaa.bz.it/sites/default/files/uploaded_files/Scuola_economia/20181_materiale_didattico2014_ECONOMIC_HISTORY_de.pdf|title=ECONOMIC HISTORY|publisher=Handelskammer Bozen|accessdate=2018-02-04}} In 2011, approximately 10% of the workplaces in all parts of the country were active in the manufacturing sector. Thus lies Tyrol in the EU average at 10.3% (2011). {{cite web|url= https://www.tirol.gv.at/fileadmin/themen/statistik-budget/statistik/downloads/Folder_T_ST_T_2015.pdf|title=Zahlen zur Europregion|publisher=Bundesland Tirol|accessdate=2018-02-04}} Important branches of industry in Tyrol are the food industry, wood processing and mechanical engineering. The industry in Tyrol consists mostly of small and medium-sized companies. The craft still plays a special role throughout the region. A large part of these craft businesses are still partially small-structured and family businesses. From an economic point of view, the energy sector is important in the secondary sector. Much of the electricity produced is generated by [[hydropower]]. ===Tertiary sector=== [[File:Riva del Garda , Panorama - panoramio.jpg|thumb|right|A known city for tourism: [[Riva del Garda]] on [[Lake Garda]]]] The most important sector in Tyrol is the tertiary sector. Especially tourism has a special position in this region. Due to the connection of the areas by the railway in the 19th century, many villages in Tyrol developed into popular tourism locations. The construction of the Brenner motorway in the 1960s gave region in the 20th century a renewed upswing in the tourism branch. Today, [[Merano]], [[Kitzbühel]], [[Cortina d'Ampezzo|Cortina]] or [[Riva del Garda]] are among the most important tourism destinations in the Alpine region. In 2013, the [[Euroregion Tyrol-South Tyrol-Trentino|Euroregion]] counted over 80 million {{cite web|url= https://www.tirol.gv.at/fileadmin/themen/statistik-budget/statistik/downloads/Folder_T_ST_T_2015.pdf|title=Zahlen zur Europregion|publisher=Bundesland Tirol|accessdate=2018-02-04}} overnight stays in the Tyrolean region (to compare - [[Province of Rome]] in 2011: 25.8 million overnight stays). {{cite web|url= https://scenarieconomici.it/dati-provinciali-sul-turismo-deludono-roma-e-firenze-eccellenti-bolzano-venezia-e-rimini/|title=Dati Provinciali sul Turismo: deludono Roma e Firenze, eccellenti Bolzano, Venezia e Rimini.|publisher=scenarieconimici.it|accessdate=2018-02-04}} Also important for Tyrol is the trade. Among other things, the [[Bolzano#Exhibition Bolzano|Exhibition of Bolzano]] has been a meeting point for Italian and German economy already for centuries. As a transit route country, more than 2.25 million trucks (2017) drove over the [[Brenner Pass]] {{cite web|url=https://www.stol.it/Artikel/Wirtschaft/Wirtschaft/Transit-Mehr-als-2-25-Millionen-Lkw-fuhren-2017-ueber-den-Brenner|title=Transit: Mehr als 2,25 Millionen Lkw fuhren 2017 über den Brenner|publisher=stol.it|accessdate=2018-02-04}} . This means that two times more trucks travel on the Brenner Route than in all four Alpine crossing roads in Switzerland together. {{cite web|url=http://tirol.orf.at/news/stories/2682236/|title= Mehr Transit-Lkws über den Brenner als in Schweiz|publisher=tirol.orf.at|accessdate=2018-02-04}} ==Transport== Tyrol is known as a transit route. The most important route between northern and southern Europe, the Brenner route, traverses the entire region. At 1370 m above the Adriatic, the [[Brenner Pass]] is the lowest pass crossing of the [[main chain of the Alps]]. Due to the linguistic diversity and the climatic transition from [[temperate climate]] ([[alpine climate]]) to [[mediterranean climate]], the area is regarded as a bridge between the Italian and German speaking countries. ===Airports=== [[File:Flughafen Innsbruck - 12-06-05 by ralfr.jpg|thumb|right|[[Innsbruck Airport]]]] The most important airport in Tyrol is [[Innsbruck Airport]]. With over one million passengers, it is the third largest airport in Austria. {{cite web|url=https://www.flugladen.at/flughafen/innsbruck|title=Flughafen Innsbruck|publisher=flugladen.at|accessdate=2018-01-30}} Other airports in the region are in [[Bolzano Airport|Bolzano]] and [[Trento Airport|Trento]]. These do not offer regular scheduled flights and the [[Bolzano Airport]] currently offers charter flights. There are other small airfields in [[Toblach]], [[Kufstein]], [[St. Johann in Tirol]], [[Reutte]] and [[Cortina d'Ampezzo|Cortina]]. The airfield in Cortina was closed in 1976 due to a crash. ===Road transport=== Highways in Tyrol are the Brenner motorway and the Inntal motorway. The Brenner motorway runs from [[Innsbruck]] (in Austria [[Brenner Autobahn|A13]]) to Modena (in Italy [[Autostrada A22 (Italy)|A22]]). Together with the Inntal motorway from [[Innsbruck]] to [[Kufstein]] is the part of the [[European route E45]]. The dual carriageway from [[Merano]] to [[Bolzano]] (MeBo) ends in Bolzano South in the Brenner motorway. Important road section in [[Trentino]], next to the Brenner motorway, is the SS 47 (Strada Statale 47), which connects via [[Sugana Valley]] [[Trento]] with [[Padova]]. A large part of this route is dual-lane and flows into the Brenner state road (SS 12). Due to the [[Alps]], there are many [[Mountain pass|mountain passes]] that connect valleys. The most important pass roads for transit trade are the [[Reschen Pass]] and [[Brenner Pass]]. Popular pass roads include the [[Stelvio Pass]], [[Arlberg Pass]], [[Karerpass|Karer Pass]], [[Mendel Pass]] and the [[Gardena Pass]]. The Provinces of [[Trentino|Trento]] and [[South Tyrol|Bolzano]] have been responsible for the preservation and management of the state roads in their provinces since 1998. {{cite web|url=http://www.provinz.bz.it/news/de/news.asp?news_action=4&news_article_id=590799|title=ANAS-Immobilien gehen an das Land über – Vertrag nun unterzeichnet|publisher=Provinz Bozen|accessdate=2018-01-30}} ===Railways=== [[File:Nuovo Treno Val Pusteria.JPG|thumb|left|Pustertal railway]] The most important railway line in Tyrol is the Brenner Line via the [[Brenner Pass]]. The [[Brenner Railway]] was opened in 1867 and runs from [[Innsbruck]] to [[Verona]] via the cities of [[Bolzano]] and [[Trento]]. Together with the [[New Lower Inn Valley Railway|Lower Inn Valley Railway]] in [[North Tyrol]], this section of the route is part of the important European railway axis [[Berlin-Palermo railway axis|Berlin-Palermo]], which connects northern Europe with southern Europe across the Alps. With the construction of the [[Brenner Base Tunnel]] and its completion in 2027, transit traffic on the rail will be promoted and relocated. After completion, the [[Brenner Base Tunnel]], together with the [[Innsbruck bypass]], will be the longest railway tunnel in the world at 64 km and will reduce the travel time between [[Bolzano]] and [[Innsbruck]] from 2 hours to 45 minutes. {{cite web|url=http://www.tt.com/politik/landespolitik/13383174-91/tirol-und-südtirol-feierten-150-jahre-brennerbahn-mit-railjet.csp|title=Tirol und Südtirol feierten 150 Jahre Brennerbahn mit Railjet|publisher=Tiroler Tageszeitung|accessdate=2018-01-30}} {{cite web|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/wirtschaft/neuer-brenner-tunnel-mit-tempo-250-durch-die-alpen-13671819.html|title=Mit Tempo 250 durch die Alpen|publisher=Frankfurter Allgemeine|accessdate=2018-01-30}} Further important railway lines in Tyrol are the [[Arlberg railway]], [[Zillertal Railway|Zillertal railway]], [[Salzburg-Tyrol Railway|Salzburg-Tyrol railway]], [[Pustertal railway]] with continuation of the [[Drautal railway]], the [[railway line Bolzano-Merano]] and the continuation of the [[Vinschgau railway]], the [[Trento–Malè–Mezzana railway]] and the [[Trento–Venice railway|Valsugana railway]], which leads from [[Trento]] to [[Venice]] over the [[Sugana Valley]]. Cross-border connections are offered only a few. The [[ÖBB]] travels over the Brenner Pass on the [[Eurocity]] trains and several regional trains connect [[South Tyrol]] with [[North|North Tyrol]] an [[East Tyrol]]. The [[Euroregion Tyrol-South Tyrol-Trentino]] has set itself the goal of promoting and expanding cross-border connections. The aim is to shift traffic through the Alps to sustainable means of transport, thus protecting the Alpine environment. {{cite web|url=http://www.europaregion.info/de/mobilitaet-verkehr.asp|title=MOBILITÄT UND VERKEHR|publisher=Europaregion Tirol-Südtirol-Trentino}} ===Local public transport=== Many villages and communities are difficult to reach because of the large differences in altitude, so the region sets much on [[ropeway]] concepts. Although most of the [[Aerial lift|cable cars]] are located in ski resorts, they are also used for the local public transport. Known cable cars in Tyrol are the [[Ritten cable car]] in [[Bolzano]], the [[Sardagna cable car]] in [[Trento]] and the [[Nordkette Cable Car|Nordkette cable car]] in [[Innsbruck]]. Also [[funicular]] railways are being built to cope with the differences in altitude more quickly. Famous funiculars are among others the [[Hungerburgbahn]] in [[Innsbruck]] and the [[Mendel funicular]] in [[Kaltern]]. Local public transport is usually offered with intercity buses or city buses. The city of [[Innsbruck Tramway|Innsbruck]] has its own tram network. Another [[Rittnerbahn|tram]] is located in [[Ritten]]. The cities of [[Bolzano Tramway|Bolzano]], [[Meran Tramway|Merano]] and [[Trento]] formerly had their own tram network, but these were displaced and replaced by the city buses and private transport in the 50s and 60s. ==Culture== The Tyrolean culture has been cultivated for several centuries and passed on to future generations. The state border between South and North Tyrol is more a political border and is considered less as a cultural border. Many traditions are cultivated throughout the Tyrolean region and show little differences. In all cultural areas such as food, dress or customs there are many similarities. Nevertheless, the individual language groups, especially the minority languages, try to maintain and promote their own linguistic identity. ===Tyrolean cuisine === [[File:Südtiroler Speck g.g.A. aufgeschnitten.jpg|thumb|200px|left|South [[Tyrolean Speck]]]] The [[Austrian cuisine#Tyrol|Tyrolean cuisine]] has similarities with the [[Austrian cuisine]] and is characterized by its alpine influence. Also the historical influence of the former [[K.U.K. Monarchy]] can be found in the Tyrolean dishes. These include dishes such as [[goulash]], [[Kaiserschmarrn]] and [[apple strudel]] which are consumed in large parts of the [[Danube monarchy]] and today still in Tyrol. Since the region is still relatively strong agricultural and peasant today, also many peasant dishes are offered on the farms. [[Schlutzkrapfen]], [[Knödel|boiled dumplings]] or cold cuts with [[Tyrolean Speck|bacon (in German: ''Speck'')]] is eaten on the farms. {{cite web|url= https://www.tirol.at/reisefuehrer/kultur-leben/kulinarik|title=Essen und trinken in Tirol|publisher=Tirol Marketing|access-date=2018-01-21}} The Tyrolean dishes show only slight differences throughout Tyrol. Due to the Mediterranean conditions in the southern part of Tyrol, a lot of wine is grown and is therefore also an important part of the Tyrolean dish, especially in [[South Tyrol]] and [[Trentino]]. Famous wines from this area are the [[Gewürztraminer]], [[Pinot Blanc]], [[Pinot Grigio]] and [[Chardonnay]]. {{cite web|url= https://www.suedtirolwein.com/de/suedtirol-wein.html|title=Südtirol Wein|publisher=Südtirol Wein|accessdate=2018-01-21}} Furthermore, a lot of apples are grown in the Region of [[Trentino-South Tyrol]]. In this region also a food culture is cultivated with a mixture of Italian and Tyrolean specialties. {{cite web|url= https://www.suedtirol.info/de/erleben/essen-trinken|title=Essen und trinken in Südtirol|publisher=IDM Südtirol|accessdate=2018-01-21}} {{cite web|url= https://www.trentino.com/de/freizeit-aktiv/essen-trinken/|title=Essen und trinken|publisher=trentino.com|access-date=2018-01-21}} {{clear}} ===Tyrolean Rifles === [[File:Schützenkompaniecastelam.jpg|thumb|right|Trentino Rifle Company in front of [[Castle of Castellano]]]] The Tyrolean Rifles were a militia organised in case of an attack on [[Crown land (Austria)|crown land]], which required Tyrol to defend its territory. The militia consisted mostly of citizens and peasants who were responsible only for the defence of their own land and were not obliged to go to war on behalf of the [[Habsburg Monarchy]]. They were authorised by an order signed by [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor Maximilian I]] in 1511 that remained valid until 1918. The Tyrolean Rifles became known in [[Tyrolean Rebellion|1809]] when Tyrolese peasants rose up and fought against the French-Bavarian occupation under [[Napoleon]]. The ensuing four [[Battles of Bergisel]] were led by [[Andreas Hofer]]. The Rifles were also used in [[World War I]] in 1915 on the [[Dolomite front]]. After the separation of Tyrol and the downfall of the monarchy, the companies also lost their task of defending their country. Nevertheless, they remained as a non-governmental organization. Today, the Rifles are responsible as an organization for the preservation of the Tyrolean culture and are always present at important political events in Tyrol. {{cite web|url= https://schuetzen.com/organisation/ssb/ueber-uns/|title=Über uns|publisher=Südtiroler Schützenbund|access-date=2018-01-21}} ===Customs=== Many Tyrolean customs were created centuries ago and are passed on by the population for the next generations. Typical in the Alpine region are the many individual customs in the valleys. Due to the seclusion of the valleys, the locals developed their own customs. Many customs have been created by legends and narratives, others by the close connection to the church. There are also traditions that are cultivated everywhere in the Tyrolean region and do not differ from other valleys and villages. These customs give local people an identity and thus feel the community more connected. {{cite web|url=https://www.tirol.at/reisefuehrer/kultur-leben/brauchtum|title=Brauchtum|publisher=Tirol Marketing|access-date=2018-01-21}} File:Krampus2.jpg|[[Krampus]] in [[Toblach]]. Typical in the alpine region. File:Imst Schemenlaufen 2016 34.jpg|''Imster Schemenlaufen'' in [[Imst]] File:Ifinger Mountain - Herz Jesu Fires - South Tyrol.jpg|Herz Jesu Fire in whole Tyrol File:032-Egetmann-Antie.jpg|''Egetmann'' with the "''Wudelen''" in [[Tramin an der Weinstraße|Tramin]] ==Sports== Tyrol is traditionally a winter sports country. Many athletes, such as [[Gustav Thoeni]], [[Benjamin Raich]], [[Carolina Kostner]], [[Gregor Schlierenzauer]], [[Toni Sailer]] and [[Armin Zoeggeler]] have already won overall World Cups and medals at World Championships and Olympic Games. Even in summer sports, several athletes from Tyrol were and still are among the best in the world. In water jumping [[Tania Cagnotto]] and [[Klaus Dibiasi]] won several medals. In cycling, [[Francesco Moser]] won the [[Giro d'Italia]]. [[Andreas Seppi]] played against the best tennis players in the world for many years. In [[bouldering]] [[Anna Stöhr]] was one of the best in the world. Many Tyrolean mountaineers such as [[Reinhold Messner]] and [[Hans Kammerlander]] influenced the [[alpinism]]. ===Soccer=== The [[FC Wacker Innsbruck (2002)|FC Wacker Innsbruck]] is one of the most traditional and successful clubs in Austria. Since the club was founded in 1915 and several name changes, the football club has won ten times the Austrian Championship and seven times the Austrian Cup. In 1987, it reached the semi-finals of the [[UEFA CUP]]. In 1970, the team defeated Real Madrid in Madrid. {{cite web|url= http://www.fc-wacker-innsbruck.at/2-uncategorised/1400-erfolge.html|title=Erfolge|publisher=FC Wacker Innsbruck|access-date=2018-01-28}} Currently (2018) Wacker Innsbruck plays in the "[[Austrian Football First League|Erste Liga]]" (second highest category of Austria). In the Region of [[Trentino-South Tyrol]], the [[FC Südtirol]] and [[A.C. Trento S.C.S.D.|AC Trento]] are the two most important clubs. Both teams participated in the Italian [[Serie C]] (third highest league in Italy) for several seasons. The AC Trento has a long history until 1921. {{cite web|url= http://www.actrento.com/storia/|title=storia|publisher=AC Trento|access-date=2018-01-28}} FC Südtirol was founded in 1995. {{cite web|url= http://www.fc-suedtirol.com/de/fc-südtirol/geschichte/4-0.html|title=Geschichte|publisher=FC Südtirol|access-date=2018-01-28}} AC Trento are currently (2018) playing in the Italian [[Serie D]] (fourth highest league in Italy) and FC Südtirol in [[Serie C]]. Thus, the FC Südtirol is the only professional football club in the region. ===Ice hockey=== {{multiple image | image1 = HC Bozen Players 2013-10-11.jpg | image2 = AUT, EBEL,EC VSV vs. HC TWK Innsbruck (11000457936).jpg | total_width = 300 | footer = Tyrolean derby; [[HC Bolzano]] against [[HC Innsbruck]] in the [[EBEL]]. }} Ice hockey is a very popular sport in Tyrol. Important clubs are the [[HC Bolzano]] and the [[HC Innsbruck]]. Both teams play in the [[EBEL]]. The HC Innsbruck, formerly [[EV Innsbruck]], won the Austrian championship seven times. With 19 won Italian championships, the HC Bolzano is the record champion in Italy. The club celebrated the biggest international successes by winning the [[Alpenliga]], the [[EBEL]] and the [[Six Nations Tournament (ice hockey)|Six Nations Tournament]] with [[Jaromír Jágr]]. {{cite web|url=https://www.hcb.net/de/verein/hall-of-fame-2/|title=Hall of fame|publisher=HC Bozen|accessdate=2018-01-28}} The Italian ice hockey league consists mostly of South Tyrolean teams. 5 of the 8 Italian teams in the [[Alps Hockey League]] come from South Tyrol ([[HC Neumarkt-Egna]], [[HC Pustertal]], [[Ritten Sport]], [[HC Gardena]] and [[WSV Sterzing Broncos]]). In this league three more Tyrolean teams play ([[SG Cortina]], [[HC Fassa]] and [[EC Kitzbühel]]). In 2005, the [[2005 Men's World Ice Hockey Championships|Ice Hockey World Championship]] was held in [[Innsbruck]] and Vienna. The [[1994 Men's World Ice Hockey Championships|1994 Ice Hockey World Championship]] took place in [[Bolzano]], [[Canazei]] and Milan. ===Volleyball=== In volleyball, [[Trentino Volley]] is one of the best teams in the world. Three times the [[CEV Champions League|Champions league]] title, four times the club [[FIVB Volleyball Men's Club World Championship|world championship]] title and four times the [[Italian Volleyball League|Italian championship]] title could win the club from [[Trento]]. Founded in 2000, the club quickly established itself at the top of the league. {{cite web|url=http://www.trentinovolley.it/pagine/dettaglio/la_societa,2/societa,5.html|title=Società|publisher=Trentino Volley|accessdate=2018-01-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180205190548/http://www.trentinovolley.it/pagine/dettaglio/la_societa,2/societa,5.html|archivedate=2018-02-05|df=}} In 2011, [[Trentino Volley]] won the [[2010–11 CEV Champions League|CEV Champions League]] ahead of its own fans at the [[PalaOnda]] in [[Bolzano]]. {{cite web|url=http://www.trentinovolley.it/news/notizie/8211-articolop-finale.html|title=Anche il Kazan si arrende, Trentino BetClic Campione d'Europa per la terza volta consecutiva!|publisher=Trentino Volley|accessdate=2018-01-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111123021329/http://www.trentinovolley.it/news/notizie/8211-articolop-finale.html|archivedate=2011-11-23|df=}} [[Hypo Tirol Innsbruck]] conquered the Austrian title 10 times. Of the last 13 seasons, the team won 10 times the Austrian championship. Since the season 2017/18 the club plays in the German volleyball league under the name "Hypo Tirol Alpenvolleys Haching". The club went into cooperation with the German team [[TSV Unterhaching]]. {{cite web|url=https://www.volleyball-bundesliga.de/cmsSupport/article/article.xhtml?articleId=59038031|title=Evers: „Die Wildcard ist eine echte Alternative“|publisher=Volleyball Bundesliga|accessdate=2018-01-28}} ===Sports events=== [[File:Zielgelände Kitzbühel.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Alpine Skiing World Cup in [[Kitzbühel]]]] In Tyrol, the [[Olympic Winter Games]] have been organized three times so far. In [[1964 Winter Olympics|1964]] and [[1976 Winter Olympics|1976]] they were held in [[Innsbruck]] and [[1956 Winter Olympics|1956]] in [[Cortina d’Ampezzo|Cortina]]. Most of the big annual sporting events in Tyrol take place in winter. The [[Alpine Skiing World Cup]] is held in [[Kitzbühel]], [[Val Gardena]], [[Cortina d'Ampezzo|Cortina]] and [[Madonna di Campiglio]]. These races are classics in the Ski World Cup and have a long tradition. A famous [[biathlon]] location is in [[Antholz]]. There were often held the Biathlon World Championships. Several [[Nordic Combined]] World Championships were organized in [[Val di Fiemme]]. Part of the [[Four Hills Tournament]] is the [[Bergisel Ski Jump]] in Innsbruck. A stage of the [[Tour de Ski]] is also located in [[Toblach]]. Some summer sports events are also held in Tyrol. The [[Tour of the Alps]] take place every year in Tyrol. The tour was launched by the [[Euroregion Tyrol-South Tyrol-Trentino]]. It is the successor of the [[Giro del Trentino]], which has been around for over 40 years. {{cite web|url=http://www.europaregion.info/de/euregio-tour-of-the-alps.asp|title=TOTA – TOUR OF THE ALPS DER EUREGIO|publisher=Europaregion Tirol-Südtirol-Trentino|accessdate=2018-01-28}} In 2017, the UCI [[Downhill mountain biking|Downhill]] World Championships took place in [[Val di Sole]], near [[Trento]]. The [[BOclassic]] in [[Bolzano]] takes place on New Year's Eve and is one of the best occupied New Year's Eve races in the world. {{cite web|url=https://www.suedtirol.com/event/69/silvesterlauf-boclassic|title=Silvesterlauf BOclassic|publisher=südtirol.com|accessdate=2018-01-28}} Every year, an [[ATP World Series]] tennis tournament is organized in [[Austrian Open Kitzbühel|Kitzbühel]]. ==Universities and research institutions== [[File:Facoltà di Economia - Università degli Studi di Trento.jpg|thumb|right|Faculty of Economics – [[University of Trento]]]] [[File:Hauptgebäude der Universität Innsbruck.jpg|thumb|right|Main building of [[University of Innsbruck]]]] [[File:Unibz.jpg|thumb|right|Main building of [[Free University of Bozen-Bolzano]]]] ===Universities=== * [[University of Innsbruck]] * [[University of Trento]] * [[Free University of Bozen-Bolzano]] * [[UMIT - Private University for Health Sciences, Medical Informatics and Technology]] * [[Medical University of Innsbruck]] ===Colleges === * [[Philosophical-theological Academy Brixen]] * [[Bolzano#Conservatory "Claudio Monteverdi"|Conservatory "Claudio Monteverdi"]] * [[Tyrolean State Conservatory]] * [[University of Applied Sciences Kufstein]] * [[Health university of Applied Science Tyrol]] * [[MCI Management Center Innsbruck]] * [[Pedagogical University of Applied Science Tyrol]] * [[Ecclesiastical Pedagogical University of Applied Science – Edith Stein]] * [[Bolzano#State College of Health Professions "Claudiana"|State College of Health Professions "Claudiana"]] === Independent research institutions=== * [[Institute for Interdisciplinary Mountain Research]]; is a facility of [[Austrian Academy of Sciences]] * [[Eurac Research]] * [[Bolzano#NOI Techpark|NOI Techpark]] * [[Foundation Bruno Kessler]] * [[Edmund Mach Foundation]] * [[Research Centre Laimburg]] ==See also== * [[Euroregion Tyrol-South Tyrol-Trentino]] * [[County of Tyrol]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Tyrol (region)| ]] [[Category:Divided regions]]
